elements.content: Six new coordination polymers, namely, [Cd3(L)2(dpa)2(H2O)] (1), [Co3(L)2(dpa)2(H2O)2]·H2O (2), [Cd(L)(chda)0.5] (3), [Cd(L)(dc)0.5(H2O)] (4), [Cd2(L)2(cca)]·2H2O (5), and [Cd2(L)2(cppa)]·2H2O (6) [HL = 3,5-di(imidazol-1-yl)benzoic acid, H2dpa = diphenic acid, H2chda = 1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylic acid, H2dc = 1,4-benzenediacrylic acid, H2cca = 4-carboxycinnamic acid, H2cppa = 3-(4-carboxyphenyl)propionic acid] have been obtained under hydrothermal conditions. Complexes 1 and 2 are novel (3,6)-connected three-dimensional (3D) frameworks based on trinuclear subunits. Complex 3 shows a rare 4-fold interpenetrating 3D dmc net, and 4 features a uninodal 6-connected 3D self-penetrating framework. Both 5 and 6 possess unusual 3-fold interpenetrating 3D (3,4)-connected InS nets. In 1−6 each metal atom is coordinated by the combination of L− and auxiliary carboxylate ligands. In 1 and 2 the auxiliary carboxylate ligand plays an important role in the formation of metal cluster based subunits. In 3−6 the auxiliary carboxylate ligands pillar the metal - L− two-dimensional networks to form entangled 3D frameworks. Furthermore, the photoluminescence and thermal stabilities of complexes 1−6 were investigated. The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility measurements of compound 2 show the ferromagnetic interactions between the metal centers mediated through the μ-O and/or O−C−O linkages.

elements.content: A systematic investigation on imidazole- and carboxylate-containing tripodal ligand together with a series of dicarboxylate was carried out, and the effect of metal ions and auxiliary carboxylate ligands on the structure of the complexes was discussed.

elements.content: Metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) with an entangled structure have attracted great attention in recent years owing to their intriguing features and topologies as well as their unique properties, such as adsorption, energy-saving materials, catalysts, and so on. The interpenetrating net is one of the most investigated and common type of entanglement, while self-penetrating coordination complexes are much rarely reported. elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with an entangled structure have attracted great attention in recent years owing to their intriguing features and topologies as well as their unique properties, such as adsorption, energy-saving materials, catalysts, and so on. The interpenetrating net is one of the most investigated and common type of entanglement, while self-penetrating coordination complexes are much rarely reported. It is known that the long rigid and slim ligands may benefit to form large voids, and the resulting complexes may have a good tendency for the formation of interpenetrated structures.

elements.content: So far many interpenetrating/self-penetrating nets constructed by mixed linkers, and the main advantage of using the mixed linkers over the single one resides in the opportunity to control the pore size and surface properties by modifying one linker without changing the overall structure dramatically, which is typically observed in the pillared-layer structures. Challenges still remain in the design and synthesis of heteroleptic entangled frameworks since the self-assembly of heteroleptic complex necessitates the preferential selection of two or more types of ligands from a mixture while avoiding formation of the alternative homoleptic complexes. On the other hand, it has been reported that the combination of carboxylate-containing ligand and bifunctional N-containing ligand could be favorable for the formation of heteroleptic pillared-layer structures. Obviously, the interlayer distances could be tuned by the pillars. The entangled heteroleptic pillared layer structures could be expected with the existence of long and slim pillars and large apertures within the layer structure. We have combined these two structural features, entangled units as well as pillared-layer motifs into the whole structure. In this work, planar imidazole-containing ligand, 3,5-di(imidazol-1-yl)benzoic acid (HL), and linear carboxylate-containing ligands with different lengths and rigidities, namely, 1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylic acid (H2chda), 1,4-benzenediacrylic acid (H2dc), 4-carboxycinnamic acid (H2cca), 3-(4-carboxyphenyl)propionic acid (H2cppa), were applied as the mixed linkers. Ligand diphenic acid (H2dpa) was also used in comparison. Six new coordination polymers [Cd3(L)2(dpa)2(H2O)] (1), [Co3(L)2(dpa)2(H2O)2]·H2O (2), [Cd(L)(chda)0.5] (3), [Cd(L)(dc)0.5(H2O)] (4), [Cd2(L)2(cca)]·2H2O (5), and [Cd2(L)2(cppa)]·2H2O (6) were synthesized and characterized by elemental analysis (EA), infrared (IR), X-ray crystallography, and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). Topological analysis and photoluminescence in the solid state were investigated. Furthermore, the magnetic and nonlinear optical properties of Co(II) complex 2 were also studied.

elements.content: All commercially available chemicals and solvents are of reagent grade and were used as received without further purification. The HL ligand was synthesized according to the method reported previously. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer at the analysis center of Nanjing University. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out on a simultaneous SDT 2960 thermal analyzer under nitrogen with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 from room temperature to 600 °C. FT-IR spectra were recorded in the range of 400−4000 cm−1 on a Bruker Vector22 FT-IR spectrophotometer using KBr pellets. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were measured on a Shmadzu XRD-6000 X-ray diffractometer. The second-order nonlinear optical (NLO) intensity was estimated by measuring a powder sample of 80−150 μm diameters in the form of a pellet relative to urea. A pulsed Q-switched Nd:YA Glaser at a wavelength of 1064 nm was used to generate second harmonic generation (SHG) signal from powder samples. The backscattered SHG light was collected by a spherical concave mirror and passed through a filter that transmits only 532 nm radiation. The luminescence spectra for the powdered solid samples were measured at room temperature on an Aminco Bowman Series2 spectrofluorometer with a xenon arc lamp as light source. In the measurements of emission and excitation spectra, the pass width is 5 nm. All measurements were carried out under the same experimental conditions. The magnetic measurements in the temperature range of 1.8−300 K were carried out on a Quantum Design MPMS7 SQUID magnetometer in a field of 2 kOe. Diamagnetic corrections were made with Pascal’s constants for all samples.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

All commercially available chemicals and solvents are of reagent grade and were used as received without further purification. The HL ligand was synthesized according to the method reported previously. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer at the analysis center of Nanjing University. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out on a simultaneous SDT 2960 thermal analyzer under nitrogen with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 from room temperature to 600 °C. FT-IR spectra were recorded in the range of 400-4000 cm-1 on a Bruker Vector22 FT-IR spectrophotometer using KBr pellets. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were measured on a Shmadzu XRD-6000 X-ray diffractometer. The second-order nonlinear optical (NLO) intensity was estimated by measuring a powder sample of 80-150 μm diameters in the form of a pellet relative to urea. A pulsed Q-switched Nd:YA Glaser at a wavelength of 1064 nm was used to generate second harmonic generation (SHG) signal from powder samples. The backscattered SHG light was collected by a spherical concave mirror and passed through a filter that transmits only 532 nm radiation. The luminescence spectra for the powdered solid samples were measured at room temperature on an Aminco Bowman Series2 spectrofluorometer with a xenon arc lamp as light source. In the measurements of emission and excitation spectra, the pass width is 5 nm. All measurements were carried out under the same experimental conditions. The magnetic measurements in the temperature range of 1.8-300 K were carried out on a Quantum Design MPMS7 SQUID magnetometer in a field of 2 kOe. Diamagnetic corrections were made with Pascal's constants for all samples.

elements.content: The crystallographic data for 1, 3−6 were collected on a Bruker Smart Apex CCD area-detector diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 20(2) °C using the ω-scan technique. The diffraction data were integrated by using the SAINT program, which was also used for the intensity corrections for the Lorentz and polarization effects. Semiempirical absorption correction was applied using the SADABS program. The structures were solved by direct methods, and all non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically on F 2 by the full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXL-97 crystallographic software package. The ligands cca2− in 5 and cppa2− in 6 are static disordered, where atoms C16 and C17 show site occupancy factors of 0.50. Each atom of C15, C18, and C19 in 6 is disordered into two positions with site occupancy factors of 0.580(13) and 0.420(13), respectively. The hydrogen atoms of ligands in 1, 3−6 were generated geometrically. Hydrogen atoms of water molecules (O5) in 4 were located directly. The crystallographic data for 2 were collected on a Rigaku RAXIS-RAPID imaging plate diffractometer at −73 °C, with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71075 Å). The structure was solved by direct methods with SIR92 and expanded using Fourier techniques. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by the full-matrix least-squares method on F 2. All calculations were carried out on SGI workstation using the teXsan crystallographic software package of Molecular Structure Corporation. The hydrogen atoms of ligands in 2 were generated geometrically. Details of the crystal parameters, data collection, and refinements for 1−6 are summarized in Table . Selected bond lengths and angles for 1−6 are listed in . Further details are provided in the .

elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Syntheses, PXRD, and Thermal Stabilities of the Complexes

In 1-6, the carboxylate groups of HL and the auxiliary ligands are completely deprotonated, which was confirmed by crystallographic analysis as well as the IR spectral data, since the vibration bands in the range of 1760-1680 cm-1 corresponding to -COOH functional group were diminished in the IR spectra of 1-6 (see ). The phase purities of the complexes were confirmed by PXRD measurements, and each PXRD pattern of the as-synthesized sample is very consistent with the simulated one ().

elements.content: In order to investigate the mobility of the solvent molecules within the MOFs, TGA was carried out for 1−6, and the results are shown in . Complex 1 shows a weight loss of 1.62% in the temperature range of 140−190 °C, which is attributed to the release of the coordinated water molecules (calc 1.34%), and the decomposition of the residue occurs at 360 °C. Complex 2 shows a weight loss of 5.06% in the temperature range of 70−200 °C, which is attributed to the release of the free and coordinated water molecules (calc 4.44%), and the decomposition of the backbone occurs at 320 °C. No obviously weight loss was found for complex 3 before the decomposition of the framework occurred at about 390 °C. For 4, there is a weight loss of 4.04% in the temperature range of 40−90 °C corresponding to the departure of the coordinated water molecules (calc 3.66%), and further weight loss is observed at about 360 °C. Complex 5 shows a weight loss of 4.00% in the temperature range of 160−200 °C, which is attributed to the release of the free water molecules (calc 3.76%), and the decomposition of the backbone occurs at 310 °C. For 6, there is a weight loss of 4.04% in the temperature range of 60−190 °C corresponding to the departure of the free water molecules (calc 3.75%), and further weight loss is observed at about 340 °C.

elements.content: The results of X-ray crystallographic analysis revealed that complex 1 crystallizes in monoclinic C2/c space group (Table ). There are three different Cd(II) atoms, two L− and two dpa2− ligands, and one coordinated water molecule in the asymmetric unit. As shown in Figure a, the Cd1 atom is seven-coordinated with pentagonal bipyramid coordination geometry by two chelate carboxylate groups (O5, O6, O9, O10) from two distinct dpa2− ligands, one chelate carboxylate group (O1A and O2A), and one nitrogen atom (N7A) from two L− ligands. The average Cd1−O bond length is 2.41 Å and the Cd1−N one is 2.257(5) Å (). The atoms O6 and N7A occupy the apical positions of the pentagonal bipyramid and the other five coordinating atoms form the basal plane. Each Cd2 atom is six-coordinated in a slightly distorted octahedral coordination geometry by four oxygen atoms (O5, O7, O9, O11) from two different dpa2− ligands with an average Cd2−O bond distance of 2.32 Å, and two nitrogen atoms (N1 and N5) from two distinct L− with Cd2−N bond lengths of 2.281(4) and 2.312(5) Å, respectively (). In 1 the Cd3 atom is six-coordinated with distorted octahedral coordination geometry by two oxygen atoms (O7, O11) from two distinct dpa2− ligands, one carboxylate group (O3A, O4A), and one nitrogen atom (N3A) from two different L− ligands, and one terminal water molecule (O13) with an average Cd3−O bond distance of 2.34 Å and Cd3−N of 2.297(5) Å (). It is interesting to note that two dpa2− ligands link three Cd(II) atoms together to form a trinuclear subunit, where these two carboxylate groups of each dpa2− ligand adopt μ2-η1:η2 bridging and μ2-η0:η2 bridging modes, respectively. Within the trinuclear subunit, the intermetallic distances of Cd1···Cd2 and Cd2···Cd3 are 3.82 Å and 3.70 Å, respectively (Figure b). The trinuclear subunits are connected by L− ligands to form a one-dimensional (1D) ladder structure along the c axis and a two-dimensional (2D) (4·82) network in the bc plane (). These two types of structures fused together to generate the ultimate three-dimensional (3D) framework of 1 (Figure c).

elements.content: To better understand the complicated 3D structure of 1, topological analysis was carried out. The above-mentioned trinuclear subunit can be viewed as a six-connected node since it links six different L− ligands, and the L− ligand can be considered as a three-connector. Such connectivity repeats infinitely to give the 3D framework of 1 as schematically shown in Figure d. According to the simplification principle, the resulting structure of 1 is a trinodal (3,3,6)-connected net with its Point (Schläfli) symbol of (4·6·8) (42·6) (43·66·86).

elements.content: When CoCO3, instead of CdCO3 for the preparation of 1, was used to react with HL and H2dpa ligands, complex 2 with a completely different structure was isolated. Complex 2 crystallized in the orthorhombic acentric Pca21 space group with a flack parameter of 0.444(19), rather than monoclinic C2/c space group in 1 (Table ). There are three different Co(II) atoms, two L− and two dpa2− ligands, two coordinated and one uncoordinated water molecules in the asymmetric unit. As shown in Figure a, all the Co(II) atoms in 2 are six-coordinated with distorted octahedral geometry, while in 1 one Cd(II) atom is seven-coordinated with pentagonal bipyramid geometry. The Co1 is coordinated by two oxygen atoms (O7 and O9) from two different dpa2−, one oxygen atom (O3), and two nitrogen atoms (N12 and N132A) from three distinct L− ligands and one coordinated water molecule (O13). Each Co2 is coordinated by four oxygen atoms (O5, O7, O9, and O11) from two dpa2− and two oxygen atoms (O4 and O1A) from two different L− ligands. The Co3 is coordinated by two oxygen atoms (O5 and O11) from two distinct dpa2− ligands, one oxygen atom (O2A) and two nitrogen atoms (N32A, N112A) from three different L− ligands and one coordinated water molecule (O14). In 2 a linear trinuclear subunit, as observed in complex 1, is generated by the connection between two dpa2− ligands and three Co(II) atoms. Each carboxylate group of dpa2− ligand adopts a μ2-η0:η2 bridging mode. The intermetallic distances of Co1···Co2 and Co2···Co3 are 3.21 Å and 3.19 Å, respectively (). In 2 the L− ligands connect the trinuclear subunits to form a 6 3 -hcb 2D layer in the bc plane (Figure b,c), which are further linked together by the trinulear Co(II) subunits in an -ABCDA- sequence along the a axis to result a 3D structure (Figure d).

elements.content: When the auxiliary ligand was changed from H2dpa used in the preparation for 1 to H2chda, complex 3 was isolated. There is one Cd(II) atom, one L−, and half chda2− ligand in the asymmetric unit of 3. There is no coordinated or lattice water molecule in 3, although it was synthesized in aqueous solution. In 3, the Cd(II) atom is six-coordinated by two chelate carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1A, O2A) and two imidazole nitrogen atoms (N1A, N3) from three distinct L− ligands, and two chelate carboxylate oxygen atoms (O3, O4) from the chda2− ligand (Figure a). On the other hand, each L− ligand links three Cd(II) atoms to form a 2D puckered network with (4,82) topology (Figures b and ), which is further pillared by the chda2− ligands to give a 3D framework (Figure c).

elements.content: In order to further understanding of the influence of auxiliary carboxylate ligand on the self-assembly process, a longer rigid ligand H2dc was used to react with CdCO3 and ligand HL and complex 4 was obtained. There are one Cd(II) atom, one L− and half dc2− ligand, and one coordinated water molecule in the asymmetric unit of 4 (Figure a). The Cd(II) is seven-coordinated with pentagonal bipyramid geometry by two chelate carboxylic oxygen atoms (O1A and O2A) and one nitrogen atom (N1) from two different L− ligands, three oxygen atoms (O3, O4, and O4B) from two distinct dc2− ligands and one coordinated water molecule (O5). Two Cd(II) atoms are linked together by two carboxylate groups from two dc2− ligands to form a [Cd2(OCO)2] subunit, where the carboxylate group adopts a μ2-η1:η2 bridging mode. The [Cd2(OCO)2] units are connected by the dc2− ligands to generate a 1D chain (). The 1D chain structures show an -AAA- packing pattern in the b axis and an -ABAB- packing pattern in the c axis (Figure b). Each L− ligand bridges two Cd(II) atoms to form a double-stranded helix with an alternate arrangement of right- and left-handed chirality along the b axis, where one imidazole group of L− ligand is free of coordination. The helices are further linked by the binuclear subunits to form an interpenetrating 2D (4, 4) topological networks (Figures c and ), which are pillared by the dc2− ligands to the resulting 3D framework (Figure d).

elements.content: Compounds 5 and 6 crystallize in the same monoclinic space group P21/c with similar cell parameters (Table ), and single crystal X-ray diffraction analyses revealed that they essentially have the same framework structure; thus only the structure of 5 is described here in detail. There are one Cd(II) atom, one L− and half cca2− ligands, and one free water molecule in the asymmetric unit of complex 5. Each Cd1 is six-coordinated with distorted octahedral geometry by two nitrogen atoms (N1A, N3A) and one chelate carboxylate group (O1, O2) from three distinct L− ligands, and one chelate carboxylate group (O3, O4) from one cca2− ligand (Figure a). On the other hand, each L− links three Cd(II) to form a typical 2D 6 3 -hcb network with an -ABAB- packing diagram along the c axis (Figures b and ), which are further pillared by the cca2− ligands to the resulting 3D framework (Figure c). As shown in Figure d, each Cd(II), L− and cca2− can be viewed as four-, three-, and two-connectors, respectively. Thus, complex 5 is a binodal (3, 4) connected framework with Point (Schläfli) symbol of (63)(65·8), which is referred to as InS topology.

Crystal Structures of [Cd2(L)2(cca)]⋅2H2O (5) and [Cd2(L)2(cppa)]⋅2H2O (6)

Compounds 5 and 6 crystallize in the same monoclinic space group P21/c with similar cell parameters (Table ), and single crystal X-ray diffraction analyses revealed that they essentially have the same framework structure; thus only the structure of 5 is described here in detail. There are one Cd(II) atom, one L- and half cca2- ligands, and one free water molecule in the asymmetric unit of complex 5. Each Cd1 is six-coordinated with distorted octahedral geometry by two nitrogen atoms (N1A, N3A) and one chelate carboxylate group (O1, O2) from three distinct L- ligands, and one chelate carboxylate group (O3, O4) from one cca2- ligand (Figure a). On the other hand, each L- links three Cd(II) to form a typical 2D 6  3  -hcb network with an -ABAB- packing diagram along the c axis (Figures b and ), which are further pillared by the cca2- ligands to the resulting 3D framework (Figure c). As shown in Figure d, each Cd(II), L- and cca2- can be viewed as four-, three-, and two-connectors, respectively. Thus, complex 5 is a binodal (3, 4) connected framework with Point (Schläfli) symbol of (63)(65⋅8), which is referred to as InS topology.

elements.content: During the syntheses of complexes 1 and 2, the same auxiliary carboxylate ligand was used, and the similar trinuclear subunits are observed in both compounds. However, the resulting structures are different, which could be ascribed to the different nature of metal ions (e.g., ion radius, coordination number, and geometry). In 1 one of three Cd(II) atoms is seven-coordinated, the other two are six-coordinated, while in 2 all the three Co(II) are six-coordinated. As a result, the L− ligands in 1 are directed by metal ions to form a (4·82) 2D structure, and in 2 the L− ligands are orientated to form a 6 3 -hcb 2D layer.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Comparison

During the syntheses of complexes 1 and 2, the same auxiliary carboxylate ligand was used, and the similar trinuclear subunits are observed in both compounds. However, the resulting structures are different, which could be ascribed to the different nature of metal ions (e.g., ion radius, coordination number, and geometry). In 1 one of three Cd(II) atoms is seven-coordinated, the other two are six-coordinated, while in 2 all the three Co(II) are six-coordinated. As a result, the L- ligands in 1 are directed by metal ions to form a (4⋅82) 2D structure, and in 2 the L- ligands are orientated to form a 6  3  -hcb 2D layer.

elements.content: It is known that multicarboxylate ligands are good candidates for the construction of MOFs with specific structures and topologies due to their varied coordination modes. In 1 and 2, the two carboxylate groups of dpa2− ligand are neighbors to each other, and a certain number of metal ions can be bridged together by the intercooperation of these two carboxylate groups. So the formation of metal cluster could be expected. In complexes 3−6 the relative long and slim auxiliary carboxylate ligands were employed to pillar the 2D layers constructed by L− ligands and metal ions, and large voids can be created between the layer structures, which made it possible for the occurrence of interpenetrating and self-penetrating, while in 1 and 2 the presence of highly connected metal clusters may suppress the interpenetration/self-penetration within the structures.

In complexes 3-6 the relative long and slim auxiliary carboxylate ligands were employed to pillar the 2D layers constructed by L- ligands and metal ions, and large voids can be created between the layer structures, which made it possible for the occurrence of interpenetrating and self-penetrating, while in 1 and 2 the presence of highly connected metal clusters may suppress the interpenetration/self-penetration within the structures.

elements.content: In 3, 5, and 6, each L− ligand bridges three metal ions acting as a three-connector, and (4,82) and 6 3 -hcb 2D layers were observed in 3 and 5/6, respectively. In 4 one imidazole group of L− ligand is free of coordination, and a (4,4) net is obtained consequently. Since the macrocycles constructed by L− ligand and metal ions within the (4,82) and 6 3 -hcb net are relatively large compared to that in the (4,4) net, the high-fold interpenetration was observed in complexes 3, 5, and 6.

elements.clean_text:
Nonlinear Optical Property of 2 

It is known that only the non-centrosymmetric structure might have a second-order nonlinear optical effect. Complex 2 crystallized in the acentric space groups Pca21, which belongs to the polar point group of C 2v . Approximate estimations were carried out on a pulsed Q-switched Nd:YA Glaser at a wavelength of 1064 nm. The results obtained from a powdered sample (80-150 μm diameters) in the form of a pellet (Kurtz powder test) were compared with those obtained for urea. The preliminary experimental results revealed that 2 exhibits modest powder SHG intensity with a response 0.6 times that for urea.

elements.content: The photoluminescence properties of complexes 1−6, together with free ligands of HL, H2dpa, H2chda, H2dc, H2cca, and H2cppa, were studied in the solid state at room temperature. Intense emission bands were observed at 426, 458, 406, and 441 nm for the free H2dpa, H2dc, H2cca, and H2cppa with excitation at 360 nm, respectively. No obvious luminescence was observed under the same experimental conditions for free HL and H2chda (). As shown in Figure , intense bands were observed at 428 nm (λex = 355 nm) for 1, 428 nm (λex = 360 nm) for 3, 434 nm (λex = 358 nm) for 4, 440 nm (λex = 360 nm) for 5, respectively, and weak bands were observed at 425 nm (λex = 360 nm) for 6. Compound 2 shows no obvious luminescence. The emission band of complex 3 may be tentatively assigned to ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT), since no obvious luminescence was found for free ligands in 3. The emissions of complexes 1 and 4−6 may be a mixture of characters of intraligand and ligand-to-ligand charge transition (LLCT). And the observed red or blue shift of the emission maximum between the complexes and the ligands was considered to mainly originate from the influence of the coordination of the ligand to metal atom.

Photoluminescence Property

The photoluminescence properties of complexes 1-6, together with free ligands of HL, H2dpa, H2chda, H2dc, H2cca, and H2cppa, were studied in the solid state at room temperature. Intense emission bands were observed at 426, 458, 406, and 441 nm for the free H2dpa, H2dc, H2cca, and H2cppa with excitation at 360 nm, respectively. No obvious luminescence was observed under the same experimental conditions for free HL and H2chda (). As shown in Figure , intense bands were observed at 428 nm (λex = 355 nm) for 1, 428 nm (λex = 360 nm) for 3, 434 nm (λex = 358 nm) for 4, 440 nm (λex = 360 nm) for 5, respectively, and weak bands were observed at 425 nm (λex = 360 nm) for 6. Compound 2 shows no obvious luminescence. The emission band of complex 3 may be tentatively assigned to ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT), since no obvious luminescence was found for free ligands in 3. The emissions of complexes 1 and 4-6 may be a mixture of characters of intraligand and ligand-to-ligand charge transition (LLCT). And the observed red or blue shift of the emission maximum between the complexes and the ligands was considered to mainly originate from the influence of the coordination of the ligand to metal atom.

elements.content: The temperature dependence of magnetic susceptibilities of 2 was investigated from 300 to 1.8 K with an applied magnetic field of 2000 Oe. The χM and χM T vs T curves for 2 are shown in Figure . The center-to-center distances between the two trinuclear subunits are larger than 13 Å in 2. Therefore, the magnetic interactions between the adjacent trinuclear subunits can be ignored and the interactions can be considered to occur between the two adjacent metal ions bridged by carboxylate groups within the trinuclear subunit. It is known that the magnetic analysis for the Co(II) complexes is rather complicated because of its spin−orbital coupling, and some approximate methods are applied to analyze the magnetic interactions between the Co(II) ions. For 2, the χM T value at 300 K is 9.77 emu K mol−1, which is much higher than the sum of three isolated spin-only Co(II) ions of 5.63 emu K mol−1 with g = 2.0, S = 3/2, ascribing to the contribution of Co(II) ions (Figure ). The reciprocal molar magnetic susceptibility above 30 K versus temperature obeys the Curie−Weiss law [χM −1 = (T − θ)/C] with Weiss constant, θ = −0.22 K, and the Curie Constant, C = 2.22 emu mol−1 (). The high value of C [1.875 emu K mol−1 for spin only Co(II)] and the negative θ value may be due to the spin−orbit coupling, which is remarkable for the 4T1g state of Co(II) in an octahedral ligand field. Similar to the magnetic behavior of other reported Co(II) complexes, the χM T value of 2 slowly decreases upon cooling to 30 K, which is a typical manner of spin−orbit coupling and is mainly due to the single-ion behavior of Co(II). However, the χM T value has an upturn below 30 K, and χM T reaches a maximum of 10.15 emu K mol−1 at 3 K, indicating that the ferromagnetic coupling between Co(II) ions occurs in this system and is strong enough to compensate the single-ion behavior resulting from spin−orbital coupling. The succeeding decrease in χM T vs T curve of 2 should be derived from the inter Co(II) ions antiferromagnetic interactions and/or zero field splitting (ZFS). Factually, the overall tendencies in the plot of χM T vs T exhibit mutual competition between the ferromagnetic coupling and single-ion behavior of Co(II) ions.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Property of Complex 2 

The temperature dependence of magnetic susceptibilities of 2 was investigated from 300 to 1.8 K with an applied magnetic field of 2000 Oe. The χM and χM T vs T curves for 2 are shown in Figure . The center-to-center distances between the two trinuclear subunits are larger than 13 Å in 2. Therefore, the magnetic interactions between the adjacent trinuclear subunits can be ignored and the interactions can be considered to occur between the two adjacent metal ions bridged by carboxylate groups within the trinuclear subunit. It is known that the magnetic analysis for the Co(II) complexes is rather complicated because of its spin-orbital coupling, and some approximate methods are applied to analyze the magnetic interactions between the Co(II) ions. For 2, the χM T value at 300 K is 9.77 emu K mol-1, which is much higher than the sum of three isolated spin-only Co(II) ions of 5.63 emu K mol-1 with g = 2.0, S = 3/2, ascribing to the contribution of Co(II) ions (Figure ). The reciprocal molar magnetic susceptibility above 30 K versus temperature obeys the Curie-Weiss law [χM -1 = (T - θ)/C] with Weiss constant, θ = -0.22 K, and the Curie Constant, C = 2.22 emu mol-1 (). The high value of C [1.875 emu K mol-1 for spin only Co(II)] and the negative θ value may be due to the spin-orbit coupling, which is remarkable for the 4T1g state of Co(II) in an octahedral ligand field. Similar to the magnetic behavior of other reported Co(II) complexes, the χM T value of 2 slowly decreases upon cooling to 30 K, which is a typical manner of spin-orbit coupling and is mainly due to the single-ion behavior of Co(II). However, the χM T value has an upturn below 30 K, and χM T reaches a maximum of 10.15 emu K mol-1 at 3 K, indicating that the ferromagnetic coupling between Co(II) ions occurs in this system and is strong enough to compensate the single-ion behavior resulting from spin-orbital coupling. The succeeding decrease in χM T vs T curve of 2 should be derived from the inter Co(II) ions antiferromagnetic interactions and/or zero field splitting (ZFS). Factually, the overall tendencies in the plot of χM T vs T exhibit mutual competition between the ferromagnetic coupling and single-ion behavior of Co(II) ions.

elements.content: In order to determine whether a long-range ordering occurs above 1.8 K, the ZFC and FC magnetic susceptibilities were carried out for complex 2 in 1.8−20 K at 10 Oe. The two curves, however, are overlapping in this temperature range (). The measurements of ac magnetic susceptibility reveal that neither in-phase (χ′) nor out-of-phase (χ′′) signals show maximum until 1.8 K (), excluding the occurrence of magnetic ordering above 1.8 K.

The two curves, however, are overlapping in this temperature range (). The measurements of ac magnetic susceptibility reveal that neither in-phase (χ') nor out-of-phase (χ'') signals show maximum until 1.8 K (), excluding the occurrence of magnetic ordering above 1.8 K.

elements.content: Assembly of metal salts with tripodal rigid imidazole-containing ligand 3,5-di(imidazol-1-yl)benzoic acid (HL) as well as carboxylate auxiliary ligands results in the formation of entangled pillared-layer frameworks. The ligand containing neighbored carboxylate groups shows a capability to form the metal clusters in 1 and 2, and the linear carboxylate ligands were proven to be a good candidate for constructing interpenetrating and self-penetrating architectures. Although different auxiliary ligands are employed during the self-assembly process of 3, 4, 5, and 6, the overall pillared-layer structures are retained, which would provide a promising access to the design and synthesis of functional materials by the modification of the pillar unit.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Assembly of metal salts with tripodal rigid imidazole-containing ligand 3,5-di(imidazol-1-yl)benzoic acid (HL) as well as carboxylate auxiliary ligands results in the formation of entangled pillared-layer frameworks. The ligand containing neighbored carboxylate groups shows a capability to form the metal clusters in 1 and 2, and the linear carboxylate ligands were proven to be a good candidate for constructing interpenetrating and self-penetrating architectures. Although different auxiliary ligands are employed during the self-assembly process of 3, 4, 5, and 6, the overall pillared-layer structures are retained, which would provide a promising access to the design and synthesis of functional materials by the modification of the pillar unit.

Complex 1 was synthesized by hydrothermal reaction of mixture of HL (25.4 mg, 0.1 mmol), H2dpa (24.2 mg, 0.1 mmol), CdCO3 (25.8 mg, 0.15 mmol), and 10 mL of H2O at 180 °C for 3 days. The colorless platelet crystals were obtained by filtration and washed by water and ethanol several times with a yield of 39%. Anal. calcd for C54H36Cd3N8O13 (%): C, 48.32; H, 2.70; N, 8.35. Found: C, 48.22; H, 2.63; N, 8.45. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3396(br, s), 1574(s), 1507(s), 1417(s), 1373(s), 1111(m), 1069(s), 934(m), 851(m), 776(m), 683(w), 654(w).

Complex 2 was obtained by the same procedure as that used for preparation of 1 except that CoCO3 (17.9 mg, 0.15 mmol) was used instead of CdCO3. The pink block crystals were collected by filtration and washed by water and ethanol several times with a yield of 36%. Anal. Calcd for C54H40Co3N8O15 (%): C, 53.26; H, 3.31; N, 9.20. Found: C, 53.18; H, 3.27; N, 9.10. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3386(br, s), 1574(s), 1517(s), 1415(s), 1373(s), 1110(m), 1079(s), 944(m), 857(m), 766(m), 673(w), 650(w).

cln_elements.content:
In order to investigate the mobility of the solvent molecules within the MOFs, TGA was carried out for 1−6, and the results are shown in . Complex 1 shows a weight loss of 1.62% in the temperature range of 140−190 °C, which is attributed to the release of the coordinated water molecules (calc 1.34%), and the decomposition of the residue occurs at 360 °C. Complex 2 shows a weight loss of 5.06% in the temperature range of 70−200 °C, which is attributed to the release of the free and coordinated water molecules (calc 4.44%), and the decomposition of the backbone occurs at 320 °C. No obviously weight loss was found for complex 3 before the decomposition of the framework occurred at about 390 °C. For 4, there is a weight loss of 4.04% in the temperature range of 40−90 °C corresponding to the departure of the coordinated water molecules (calc 3.66%), and further weight loss is observed at about 360 °C. Complex 5 shows a weight loss of 4.00% in the temperature range of 160−200 °C, which is attributed to the release of the free water molecules (calc 3.76%), and the decomposition of the backbone occurs at 310 °C. For 6, there is a weight loss of 4.04% in the temperature range of 60−190 °C corresponding to the departure of the free water molecules (calc 3.75%), and further weight loss is observed at about 340 °C.

Magnetic Property of Complex <bold>2</bold>

The temperature dependence of magnetic susceptibilities of 2 was investigated from 300 to 1.8 K with an applied magnetic field of 2000 Oe. The χM and χM T vs T curves for 2 are shown in Figure . The center-to-center distances between the two trinuclear subunits are larger than 13 Å in 2. Therefore, the magnetic interactions between the adjacent trinuclear subunits can be ignored and the interactions can be considered to occur between the two adjacent metal ions bridged by carboxylate groups within the trinuclear subunit. It is known that the magnetic analysis for the Co(II) complexes is rather complicated because of its spin−orbital coupling, and some approximate methods are applied to analyze the magnetic interactions between the Co(II) ions. For 2, the χM T value at 300 K is 9.77 emu K mol−1, which is much higher than the sum of three isolated spin-only Co(II) ions of 5.63 emu K mol−1 with g = 2.0, S = 3/2, ascribing to the contribution of Co(II) ions (Figure ). The reciprocal molar magnetic susceptibility above 30 K versus temperature obeys the Curie−Weiss law [χM −1 = (T − θ)/C] with Weiss constant, θ = −0.22 K, and the Curie Constant, C = 2.22 emu mol−1 (). The high value of C [1.875 emu K mol−1 for spin only Co(II)] and the negative θ value may be due to the spin−orbit coupling, which is remarkable for the 4T1g state of Co(II) in an octahedral ligand field. Similar to the magnetic behavior of other reported Co(II) complexes, the χM T value of 2 slowly decreases upon cooling to 30 K, which is a typical manner of spin−orbit coupling and is mainly due to the single-ion behavior of Co(II). However, the χM T value has an upturn below 30 K, and χM T reaches a maximum of 10.15 emu K mol−1 at 3 K, indicating that the ferromagnetic coupling between Co(II) ions occurs in this system and is strong enough to compensate the single-ion behavior resulting from spin−orbital coupling. The succeeding decrease in χM T vs T curve of 2 should be derived from the inter Co(II) ions antiferromagnetic interactions and/or zero field splitting (ZFS). Factually, the overall tendencies in the plot of χM T vs T exhibit mutual competition between the ferromagnetic coupling and single-ion behavior of Co(II) ions.
